attributes.title: Tokio Marine: Consider Shareholder Return Outlook And Potential M&A (Rating Downgrade)
summary: I rate Tokio Marine as a Hold, following an assessment of the company's capital allocation.

My key concern is that TKOMY's capital return in the years ahead might not live up to the market's expectations, considering the pace of non-core investment sales and the adoption of new accounting standards.
But TKOMF's future growth could surprise on the upside with inorganic drivers like acquisitions in the US.

attributes.content:
My rating for Tokio Marine Holdings (TKOMF) (TKOMY) (8766.JP) is a Hold.

I was previously a bull on the stock as per my October 9, 2024 write-up which highlighted its efforts to increase "Return On Equity" (or "ROE").

I'm Neutral on TKOMF after assessing the company's shareholder returns and capital investments.

There's Uncertainty Over Future Cash Distributions

Tokio could become a much less appealing investment candidate. I see a risk that the company pays out a below-expectations proportion of earnings to its shareholders going forward.

TKOMY is reliant on asset sales to fund capital allocation moves.

The company targets to lower the balance of its non-core investments to below ¥2,500 billion in the 12-month period up to end-Mar this year. It expects to divest JPY0.75 trillion of non-strategic shareholding interests in this fiscal year. This is +242% more than what it did for FY23 ("YE March 31, 2024")

My prediction is that TKOMF will realize a lower level of divestiture proceeds in the years ahead. This doesn't bode well for its capital return outlook.

Its goal is to conclude this portfolio restructuring exercise by March 31, 2030. This implies that the company's estimated annual monetization amount for the next 5-year period will be JPY 500 billion, or two-thirds of FY2024's.

The company spent ¥0.10-0.12 trillion on yearly buybacks in the FY21-23 time frame. TKOMY's future repurchases might possibly revert to more modest levels seen in the past, if it has less excess capital to deploy.

Potential Changes Pertaining To TKOMF's Adoption Of New Accounting Standards

Separately, TKOMY will be re-evaluating its framework regarding cash payouts in line with the IFRS17 ("International Financial Reporting Standard 17") implementation as detailed in the chart above.

There's a possibility that it could decrease the percentage of profit distributed to shareholders beginning on April 1, 2026. The mean dividends-to-earnings ratio for listed entities worldwide is close to 50%, or the same as Tokio's current payout. The market won't be pleased, assuming that it makes unfavorable tweaks to its existing stance on dividends.

The stock's FY24 capital management yield ("sum of buybacks and dividends divided by market capitalization") is anticipated to be a decent 4.6 percent. This figure is derived based on its current-year dividend guide and existing repurchase program expiring in mid-May '25.

Japan's MS&AD Insurance Group (MSADF) (MSADY) [8725:JP] boasts an equally attractive consensus next twelve months' dividend yield of 4.5% (source: S&P Capital IQ). If TKOMF's shareholder return isn't as competitive as its peer, investors might consider alternatives. This has prompted me to downgrade the name.

But Company Has Solid Inorganic Growth Potential

At the recent RBC Financial Institutions Conference (event report not publicly available) in early-March, TKOMF indicated that it is seeking "differentiated assets" to enhance "the franchise".

I'm not bearish on the stock despite my concerns about its dividends and buybacks. This is because the company might spring a positive surprise by doing some accretive deals.

TKOMY's History Of Acquisitions In The US

TKOMF had success in buying over North American insurance operations in the past. Its average "ROIC-WACC spread" for such transactions was over +900 bps ("basis points"). The superior returns were achieved by delivering financial improvement at acquirees and timing such purchases well.

The targets taken over by the company have subsequently expanded at a more rapid pace than their respective benchmarks, as outlined below.

The Performance Of TKOMF's Investees Post-Integration

It's time for Tokio to revisit its deal pipeline again, as the Fed is in a rate-cutting cycle now.

TKOMY's prior major M&As were done when US interest rates were low or on a declining trend. These tend to be periods where insurance markets underperformed. This throws up good chances for purchasing quality assets on the cheap.

TKOMF noted at this month's RBC investor event ("referred to above") that it is mainly focused on E&S ("Excess and Surplus") insurance in North America. This means that the company could either reinforce its presence in this space or even penetrate new insurance sub-segments with the help of acquisitions.

My Closing Thoughts

A Hold for Tokio Marine is warranted. I like TKOMF's external growth opportunities. But I'm less optimistic about its capital return.

The stock also doesn't have substantial upside or downside from the valuation angle.

P/B Equation Based On The "Gordon Growth Model"

My fair P/NAV multiple for the stock is 2.36x derived using the formulae presented in the chart above. I have assumed a 19 percent ROE ("management FY24 guidance), a "k" of 9.2% ("industry average cost of equity for non-bank financials"), and a "g" of +2% ("mature economy expansion rate").

Tokio trades at a similar 2.33 times (source: S&P Capital IQ) its book value, so I deem the company's shares to be reasonably valued.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

The Value Pendulum is an Asian equity market specialist with over a decade of experience on both the buy and sell sides.

He is the author of the investing group Asia Value & Moat Stocks, providing ideas for value investors seeking investment opportunities listed in Asia, with a particular focus on the Hong Kong market. He hunts for deep value balance sheet bargains and wide moat stocks and provides a range of watch lists with monthly updates within his investing group.
